I played this game on the ps4 and I enjoyed it! I thought it was an interesting storyline and the difficulty level on normal was good enough for me to handle (I am not great at games). However, I recently got a new pc and decided to buy the game again because I heard of all the new updates and DLC, and it is like a whole new game. The skill tree is seamless and feels like it has a lot more weight to it. The weapon system is much more understandable. I haven't got to the new DLC but I am excited to see how it adds to the story. Overall, its super fun to replay and discover new ways to play the game!

it's definitely one of my favourite game, I'm now at the last boss: the stone monkey, for me the best chapter is the Spiderweb Hollow, Loved the story and boss fight, btw, the Yellow long took me like more than 20 fights, definitely the hardest fight for me, the best part of the game would be the fighting scene and responsive moves, definitely recommend it

Really interesting to see Chinese mythology portrayed like this in a video game. Not too familiar with it personally, so it was a nice breath of fresh air. 

The combat is fun and there's a lot of build variety. Sometimes the controls can feel a bit janky (feels like commands aren't queued up properly if your character is busy in an animation so it feels like you have to spam buttons to get one command out sometimes).

The story was relatively interesting. The end chapter animations were a huge highlight and a wonderful little decompression moment after the (usually) intense chapter end bosses.

Areas looked very beautiful but I definitely felt like level design itself was a bit lacking (even if the environments were gorgeous). Some areas dragged on for far too long and were kind of samey (chapter 5 really felt like it would never end). 

Overall, I definitely enjoyed the game and felt like the time I spent with it was worth it. I'm looking forward to the DLC.

Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me twice, shame on me.  Fool me three times, uninstall the game.

The Terry Bogart DLC has just released and the pattern is now clear: They are not trying to create a balanced eSport, but are releasing OP characters to sell DLC!

Every new DLC character release is like a recreation of the Stanford Prison Experiment.  Half the players switch to the new character and get to be wardens, and half the players stick with their main character and get to be prisoners.

Having to fight a constant loop of Terry, Bison, and Akuma is not fun any more.   The only successful DLC characters were Ed and Aki.  They were different enough to attract some attention, but not so overpowered that everyone switched to them.  The pattern with Akuma, Bison, and now Terry is clear.  Buy the DLC character and you get to play as a warden.  Dont buy the character and you are a prisoner. 

I do not recommend anyone buy this.  The launch was good and surprisingly balanced, but this is now a pay2win-ish game.

Easily one of the best if not [b]the[/b] best Street Fighter to date. (Next to Third Strike)
Every match feels challenging but still winnable, it's not a snowball-fest like other games.

There's serious hype potential in every match, and the characters are varied and fun to learn.
The netcode has been pretty good to me so far, and the battle hub is hilarious to behold.

Oh, and it has a single-player adventure mode similar to ye olde Mortal Kombat Konquest!

What's not to love here? Except for maybe a pretty meager starting roster as of writing.

Hopefully SF6 has a long and prosperous future ahead of it, compared to SFV.

finally hit 100 hours, time for a collection of thoughts about the game

Pros
-feels like a older game in the gameplay sense, feels like the original gears of war games or halo
-After 100 hours im still looking foward to playing more
-Day 1 gave us a road map detailing the next year of content new maps for pve and pvp, new modes for pvp and pve, new enemies in pve, new weapons and more
-PvP is incredibly fun and isnt a grind fest to jump into the fun, hop in do some pvp, go back to pve no problem
- Gameplay as a whole is the best part of the game, its never been more fun to hop in and kill some heretics or some nids with a fury that would make the God Emperor of Mankind proud
-perk system is not overly complicated
-HIGH SKILL CEILING on higher difficulties when it comes to keeping your health afloat so long as your not using a melta weapon in which case the game is easy mode

cons

-issues with servers right now
-weapon balance needs to be fixed (bolt weapons need a fix for pve)
-certain enemies on ruthless difficulty feel way too meat spongy
-some extremis enemies will sometimes never die regardless of damage dealt sometimes which can kill runs on higher difficulties
-need more maps but they are otw

I have been playing this game off and on for the last year or so. I enjoyed the vanilla version of the game, but I really started to enjoy it with the many mods that are able to be implemented. It helps make a realistic game a little more realistic, definitely worth the cost and you can find yourself getting lost in the lore and gameplay.

The longer you survive, the more you'll care about surviving but in the beginning I couldn't even muster the motivation to care that I was dying. Everything is a chore, literally. Yes, its mechanics are deep and interesting. And I can understand why someone would find satisfaction in a game like this but if you're looking to play a game... I don't even know if this qualifies as a game. It feels more like taking care of a really shitty tamagotchi.

Before I get into the negatives, I want to be very clear: this is one of my favorite games ever. I am a huge fan of the 2018 GoW, and this game actually improves on it in nearly every way. I wish that I could be writing a positive review right now, because this game absolutely deserves it... on console.

I bought the steam port the second it came out, and ever since, it has been fundamentally broken. I have no idea why most other reviewers aren't commenting on this, but this port is unplayable as it stands. I can repeatedly cause it to crash to desktop simply by looking at the in-game menus. If you want to read the in game lore, the game will crash the second you select any other item than the one it initially opened on, eg. Kvasir's Poems. The game also crashes during certain fights seemingly at random. And all of this will occur after closing the game and reopening to play later from your last save, which is a very normal thing to do.

I am running the game on an asus zephyrus laptop, with a 3080 gpu, as well as 8gb of vram. I am well within the bounds of recommended specs, and run intensive games all the time with no problems whatsoever. I have tried almost every combination of settings, both in and out of the game, but to no avail. I have scoured what little there is online, and amazingly, turning it off and on again doesn't fix an in-game bug, or bugs.

I have to imagine that all the good reviews are from people who haven't picked up this game since the first time opening it, or who have only played it on console. When this bug, or bugs, is fixed, I will immediately come back and edit this review to be glowing. But in the meantime, I encourage everyone to stay far away until it is fixed, and play the console version instead.

Game requires a restart every so often to avoid performance loss from VRAM usage going up and up with loading and transitioning between different realms and other assets not getting flushed fast enough from GPU memory. 

If you have less than a 16GB GPU you can experience issues earlier (depending on your in-game settings and resolution) like audio de-sync, texture pop-in and crashes. There are many other issues with the use of different controllers and issues with mouse and keyboard input. 

I will now sit on the wait train for patches.

Great game on the PS5. Worst PC port I've seen in a while. They're boasting steam deck compatibility, but the controls are so broken on the deck you cannot complete certain puzzles. Essentially locking you from progressing. Something is also broken on regular PC with PlayStation controllers. Took me ages to get R1 to work, and the controller will randomly quit working. It's not the controller as it works fine on any other game I use. Also crashed a few times while fiddling in the steam controller menu. Whoever was in charge of controller/steam deck support for this game needs to get fired. It's a shame, because the game is great, but can't reccomend a game this broken. Will change if they address the issues.

I've played every GOW including the original trilogy on PS and GOWR is by far the most boring, drawn out, and uninteresting of the lot of them.
 
I have gotten to the mission with Atreus and [spoiler]Angrboda[/spoiler] and I have to take a break from this game as this mission in particular is a pungent combination of every aspect that makes this game so awful...

[*] The game features an Incredibly drawn out level design that forcefully diverts attention from the main objective without creating any sort of interest in whatever else that's going on. 
[*] The dialogue/voice acting takes away from the immersion of the mission and rarely adds anything of substance to the world (Sindri, Brock, and a few others are exceptions to this). 
[*] The combat system feels inconsistent and fights including bosses feel less "cool" then in the other games. 
[*] The puzzles/path discovery needed to advance within missions feels redundant, unoriginal, and often times unnecessary. 
[*] And IMO the armor/weapon upgrade UI feels unrefined and outdated. 

These issues are dramatically present in the mission mentioned above but are featured throughout the ~9 hours of gameplay I've experienced so far.

On the plus side the graphics and cut scenes look amazing, and the main story so far is awesome, in spite of how hard the developers tried to destroy the interesting aspects of the story through an incredibly poorly thought out gameplay experience. 

IMO this game is nowhere near worth the $60 price tag and I heavily regret spending that amount on this game. I would seriously wait for it to go on sale somewhere below the $30 mark. 

I will most likely end up completing the main story, just for nostalgias sake, and immediately uninstall it.

I'm really just not enjoying this. It's very slow moving story wise with loads of places where you can only move your character around slowly in game. I usually love games with loads of interaction between characters but so much of the dialogue is bad and dull that this is one of the few games where I want to skip scenes. Worst of all for me though is that there are permanently missable items, such as a materia at the start of the game that you can never get again if you miss it. That's just bad design.

Combat is fine. There is an option for letting your guys auto attack so you can focus on commands but if you do that battles take soooooooo long whereas they go fast if you just mash x. I can see what they were trying to do and it looks cool to watch but playing it feels unfocused and you because everything is in such frenetic action, you can't appreciate the art assets or models at all

Overall this game feels bloated and boring with intentionally slow parts padding out the play time.

I would expect nothing less from Square-Enix, but this is certainly a work of art.  Dedicated to reviving the story of Final Fantasy VII dutifully while introducing a fresh user user experience.  Graphics, Sound, Music, and Voices are outstanding,

OG FF7 was the second game I finished ever and has an immense nostalgia spot in my heart. Until today the story and characters stuck on my mind and feel like family. Now that I started playing FF7 Remake for nearly 10 hours, I need to say that this game is just awesome! You need to adopt that they added some side arcs and more depth to the characters that hadn't been there in the beginning but if you're an open minded person this add so much value to the story. I didn't think after all that critizism that I'd say that, but I love the changes and love even more to see that 95% stayed the same. Awesome! The gameplay, the music, the artstyle and everything is just on point and I'm truly in love with FF7 remake. Hope the port for Rebirth will hit Steam sooner than later.

Bro I'm playing this on a Strix GTX 960 w 12gb ram and 3ghz dual core from 12+ years ago and running this at 60fps via display port @ 1920x1080. Beyond well optimized. Its easily one of my favorite games to play right now.

Aside from running well, this game has been everything I wanted it to be and then some. Compared to the vibe of original FF7, I think this does it a lot of justice. The characters and dialogue are fun, the Shinra menace is equally pronounced etc.

The combat is so smooth I don't even know where to start. But somehow they made a turn-based FF game feel completely naturally FF in an action RPG environment. It's great.

The pacing is good, the side quests are cute and rewarding. I feel like I wasn't wasting much time if any in this game. Everything just sorta flows when you figure out the map.

I can praise this game all day. I'm on the last chapter as of today - I only have a few issues:

-The humor can be out of place sometimes along with the fan service. Particularly when you hear Tifa say 'Man I really need a shower' for the 40th time after a fight it sorta makes you raise an eyebrow, genuinely. That crap is NOT why I'm here and it's sad to me that these adults designing these games find it adds anything to this kinda game.

-I get there is world building and the game GENUINELY at times feels like a re-imagined PS1 game but at times I feel like I'm running down long hallways for no real reason. Are the narrow passages you have to side-step through like...loading screens? Some places are just too big dude. 

-Collect-a-thon. As much as I like that and enjoy it in FF games, this game goes a little too far with the ground clutter. Way too many boxes to destroy. Personally I prefer ~80% of my items to be bought/earned from fights but I'd reckon 70-80% of your important items are in yellow-lit boxes and the battle rewards are mostly for gil. Is what it is. Not necessarily a bad thing, but I would probably enjoy *an hour or 2* Less destroying boxes on the ground.

I have much love for the original version, down to every last detail. There are pros and cons for someone like myself. I love the graphics and how they've been redone. I love the voices given to the characters. I love how interactive the game is, and it doesn't have to cut to a "movie" scene as in previous Final Fantasy games. I don't mind the slight change in the leveling/batting system. It feels more fluid, yet I can access the menu to choose what I want to do for the character I'm controlling. Is it complete control over all the characters with ATB? No. However, for this remake, it feels right. Moving onto changes in the story. There are a lot I agree with, and it was nice to have a change. However, I also felt a lot didn't need a change. That is my opinion, and you must make up your own. It's still a fantastic game, and I love it.
